name: Exploring Shakespeare in Performance
description: In this course, students will be introduced to contemporary theatrical approaches to the most canonical of dramatists. Through selected theoretical readings, interviews, practical exercises, and screenings of recent productions, we will explore tensions between reverential and radical treatments of the Shakespearean text, including topics such as the politics of casting, the role of the director, and the authority of the actor. The course will ask what it means to stage Shakespeare now and will equip students to develop their own and conceptual and theatrical responses to that question. [24L, 24T]
prerequisites: Open to students who have successfully completed at least 4.0 full credits, including DRE121H5 or ENG121H5; DRE122H5 or ENG122H5; and DRE226H5.
